title: protocol - Wiktionary, the free dictionary
cleaned_text: protocol [Jump to navigation](#mw-head) a volume (on errata were written)"), from [Byzantine Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_Greek) plural [protocols](/wiki/protocols#English)) - (now chiefly [historical](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#historical)) The minutes, or official record, of a negotiation or transaction; especially a document drawn up officially which forms the legal basis for subsequent agreements based on it. [from 15th c.] - 1842, Thomas Campbell, Frederick the Great and his Times, volume II, page 47: - Another account says that, on the morning of the 31st of May, the king delivered to the prince-royal the crown, the sceptre, and the key of his treasure and gave him his blessing. The privy-counsillor Vockerodt drew up at his desire a protocol of the transaction. - ( [international law](/wiki/international_law), now [rare](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#rare)) An official record of a [diplomatic](/wiki/diplomatic)meeting or negotiation; later specifically, a draft document setting out [agreements](/wiki/agreements)to be signed into force by a subsequent formal [treaty](/wiki/treaty). [from 17th c.] - 1970, Matthew Smith Anderson, The Great Powers and the Near East, 1774-1923, page 32: - The terms of this protocol formed the basis for the Treaty of London signed by the British, French and Russian governments on 6 July 1827. - ( [international law](/wiki/international_law)) An [amendment](/wiki/amendment)to an official [treaty](/wiki/treaty). [from 19th c.] - 2002, Philippe Sands, Principles of International Environmental Law, p. 917 n. 253: - The 1992 Protocol amended the definitions of other terms, including 'ship', 'oil' and 'incident': Art. 2. - 2002, Philippe Sands, Principles of International Environmental Law, p. 917 n. 253: - The first [leaf](/wiki/leaf)of a roll of [papyrus](/wiki/papyrus), or the official [mark](/wiki/mark)typically found on such a page. [from 19th c.] - 1991, Leila Avrin, Scribes, Script, and Books, page 146: - They marked the beginning of each scroll with their protocol, a practice that continued in the papyrus trade in the Byzantine Empire [...] into the Islamic period, when there were bilingual protocols in Greek and Arabic. - The official formulas which appeared at the beginning or end of certain official documents such as [charters](/wiki/charter), papal [bulls](/wiki/bull)etc. [from 19th c.] - 1985, Archivum Historiae Pontificiae, volume 23, page 14: - The protocol of the bull contains elements that appear to be formulaic by the time of John XVIII 's pontificate. - ( [sciences](/wiki/sciences)) The original [notes](/wiki/note)of [observations](/wiki/observation)made during an [experiment](/wiki/experiment); also, the precise method for carrying out or reproducing a given experiment. [from 19th c.] - 1931, Gye & Purdy, The Cause of Cancer, page 194: - The following is an abstract of the protocol of the experiment: Tumour extract.—A measured 16 c.c. of minced Rous Sarcoma tissue was ground with sand and extracted with 400 c.c. of 0.8-per-cent. saline. - The official [rules](/wiki/rule)and [guidelines](/wiki/guideline)for [heads of state](/wiki/head_of_state)and other dignitaries, governing accepted behaviour in relations with other diplomatic representatives or over affairs of state. [from 19th c.] - 2009 September 19, Laura Johnson, "A mwah too far", in The Guardian: - Even the Queen (for whom the curtsey is a more standard address) was recently treated to an enthusiastic Obama embrace. Her Majesty, who is not normally known for partaking in such public displays of affection, seemed unperturbed by Michelle Obama's disregard for royal protocol. - (by extension) An accepted [code of conduct](/wiki/code_of_conduct); acceptable behaviour in a given situation or group. [from 20th c.] - 2010 July 16, The Guardian: - For those uncertain in the protocol of handshaking a formula for the perfect handshake has been devised by scientists at the University of Manchester. - 2020 December 2, Paul Bigland, "My weirdest and wackiest Rover yet", in Rail, page 66: [TfW](/wiki/TfW#English)has staff enforcing mask protocols at all the busy stations and most travellers oblige, albeit some with ill grace. - - ( [computing](/wiki/computing#Noun)) A set of formal rules describing how to transmit or exchange data, especially across a network. [from 20th c.] - 2001, "More Shopping", in Discosis, performed by [Bran Van 3000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bran_Van_3000)ft. [Momus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Momus_(musician)): - Moloch passed the message to the Behemoth / Whose master passed it on to Zebedee / It was sent by Internet, by obscure protocols / To its recipient, the delicious Miss Gee - 2006, Zheng & Ni, Smart Phone and Next-Generation Mobile Computing, p. 444: - An exception is Jabber, which is designed based on an open protocol called the extensible messaging and presence protocol (XMPP). - 2021 September 5, Eric Lipton, Ephrat Livni, "Crypto's Rapid Move Into Banking Elicits Alarm in Washington", in The New York Times [[1]](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/05/us/politics/cryptocurrency-banking-regulation.html), [ISSN](https://www.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331): - Founders of those kinds of platforms argue that they are just building a "protocol" ultimately led by a community of users, with the computer code effectively running the show. - - ( [medicine](/wiki/medicine)) The set of instructions allowing a licensed medical professional to start, modify, or stop a medical or patient care order. [from 20th c.] - ( [Roman Catholicism](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism)) The liturgical the [Sursum corda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sursum_corda)dialogue. - 2010, Virgilio T.J. Suerte Felipe, The Lord's Mass... What's in a Name? [...], [ISBN](/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781449060381), [pages 45-46](https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=glA-RiQxBsIC&pg=PA45): - This protocol of the Preface has been constant, with minor modification, from the Apostolic Tradition, of Hippolytus in 215 A.D., the earliest extant text of the Eucharistic Prayer, to the present 2002 Missale Romanum. - 2011, Michael S. Driscoll, J. Michael Joncas, The Order of Mass: A Roman Missal Study Edition and Workbook, [ISBN](/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781568549897), page 213: - The proper Preface for Eucharistic Prayer II also appears as Common Preface VI. In it, the protocol and body of the Preface structure are meshed. - [2022, Uwe Michael Lang, The Roman Mass: From Early Christian Origins to Tridentine Reform, [ISBN](/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781108832458), page 140: - The celebrant then takes up this response in the first part of the preface itself (also known by the technical term 'protocol'): [...]] - - ( [object-oriented programming](/wiki/object-oriented_programming)) In a [data type](/wiki/data_type) [declaring](/wiki/declare)a set of [members](/wiki/member)that must be implemented by a [class](/wiki/class)or other data type. Synonyms[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=protocol&action=edit§ion=5)] - (original notes of observations made during an experiment): [procedure](/wiki/procedure#English) - (official rules and guidelines for heads of state and other dignitaries): [procedure](/wiki/procedure#English), [policy](/wiki/policy#English) - (accepted code of conduct): [policy](/wiki/policy#English) - (data type defining a set protocol (third-person singular simple present [protocols](/wiki/protocols#English), present [protocolling](/wiki/protocolling#English), [protocolled](/wiki/protocolled#English)) - ( [obsolete](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#obsolete), protocol of. - ( [obsolete](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#obsolete), [intransitive](/wiki/Appendix:Glossary#intransitive)) To make or write protocols, or first drafts; to issue protocols. - 1837, [Thomas Carlyle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Carlyle), [The French Revolution: A History [...]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_French_Revolution:_A_History), to III), London: [Chapman and Hall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chapman_%26_Hall), [OCLC](https://www.worldcat.org/title/1026761782), (please specify the book or page number): - Serene Highnesses, who sit there protocolling and manifestoing, and consoling incomplete. You can help Wiktionary by elaborating on the origins of this term. Pronunciation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=protocol&action=edit§ion=20)] Noun[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=protocol&action=edit§ion=21)] n) [protocol](#English)(collection of rules and procedures) [protocol](#English)(book containing official documents) [protocol](#English)(official record of minutes a volume (on errata were written)"), from [Byzantine Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_Greek) J. Thomas, G. A. Bevan, P. J. Donovan, A. Hawke et al., editors (1950-present), " [protocol](http://welsh-dictionary.ac.uk/gpc/gpc.html?protocol)", in Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru Online (in Welsh), University of Wales Centre for Advanced Welsh & Celtic Studies [Categories](/wiki/Special:Categories): [English terms borrowed from Middle French](/wiki/Category:English_terms_borrowed_from_Middle_French) [English terms derived from Middle French](/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Middle_French) [English terms derived from Late Latin](/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Late_Latin) [Dutch terms derived from Middle Dutch](/wiki/Category:Dutch_terms_derived_from_Middle_Dutch) [Dutch terms French](/wiki/Category:Romanian_terms_derived_from_French) [Romanian terms terms derived from Byzantine Greek](/wiki/Category:Romansch_terms_derived_from_Byzantine_Greek)
